stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain how the kidney handles sodium?

prompts.text: Describe the structure of the nephron and where sodium is reabsorbed.
expectedKeyFacts: Nephron: glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, distal tubule, collecting duct
Proximal tubule: 65-70% sodium reabsorbed with water (iso-osmotic)
Thick ascending limb: 25% sodium reabsorbed (Na-K-2Cl cotransporter)
Distal tubule: 5% sodium reabsorbed
Collecting duct: 2-3% sodium reabsorbed (aldosterone-sensitive)
Overall >99% of filtered sodium reabsorbed
Glomerular filtration rate ~125 mL/min in adults

prompts.text: How does the loop of Henle create the concentration gradient in the medulla?
expectedKeyFacts: Countercurrent multiplier system
Descending limb: permeable to water, impermeable to sodium — water moves out, fluid becomes hypertonic
Thick ascending limb: impermeable to water, actively transports Na-K-2Cl out
Creates increasing osmotic gradient from cortex (300 mOsm) to medulla (1200 mOsm)
Vasa recta: countercurrent exchanger preserves gradient
Urea recycling in inner medulla contributes to gradient
ADH increases water permeability in collecting duct — allows concentration

prompts.text: How does aldosterone affect sodium handling and what triggers its release?
expectedKeyFacts: Mineralocorticoid acting on principal cells of collecting duct
Increases sodium reabsorption via epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
Increases potassium secretion (Na-K-ATPase activity)
Triggers: renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)
Released in response to: low BP, low sodium, high potassium
Juxtaglomerular apparatus senses low perfusion pressure — releases renin
Angiotensin II stimulates aldosterone from adrenal cortex
Effect: sodium and water retention, increased BP, potassium loss

prompts.text: What would happen if you gave a loop diuretic and where does it act?
expectedKeyFacts: Acts on Na-K-2Cl cotransporter in thick ascending limb
Blocks sodium and chloride reabsorption
Prevents concentration gradient formation
Results: sodium, chloride, potassium loss; increased urine output
Cannot concentrate urine maximally
Also inhibits calcium reabsorption — hypocalcaemia
Metabolic alkalosis: increased distal sodium delivery, K+ and H+ loss
Examples: furosemide, bumetanide
Used in fluid overload, pulmonary oedema, hyperkalaemia

prompts.text: Compare the effects of loop diuretics versus thiazide diuretics on calcium balance.
expectedKeyFacts: Loop diuretics: inhibit calcium reabsorption in thick ascending limb — hypocalcaemia, increased urinary calcium
Thiazides: enhance calcium reabsorption in distal tubule — hypercalcaemia
Thiazides block Na-Cl cotransporter in distal tubule
Loop diuretics more potent but thiazides useful in long-term HTN
Thiazides used in hypercalciuria and recurrent calcium stones
Loop diuretics used in acute hypercalcaemia with fluid resuscitation
Both cause hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system — what triggers it and what does it do?
keyFacts: ADH increases water permeability in collecting duct
Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption, potassium secretion
RAAS activated by low BP, low sodium
Loop diuretics block Na-K-2Cl, prevent concentration, cause hypocalcaemia

scoringGuidance.pass: Describes nephron segments and percentages of sodium reabsorption, explains countercurrent multiplier, understands aldosterone mechanism and RAAS, knows loop diuretic action and complications; stronger candidates compare thiazide vs loop effects on calcium
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows kidney filters and reabsorbs sodium but unclear on segments, mentions loop of Henle but mechanism vague, aware of diuretics but side effects unclear
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe nephron structure, does not understand sodium handling or concentration mechanism, unaware of aldosterone or RAAS, no knowledge of diuretic mechanisms
